title: ß-amyloid Imaging With BAY94-9172 Positron Emission Tomography for Early Detection of Alzheimer's Disease in Patients With Mild Cognitive Impairment
description_brief: The aim of the study is to investigate whether Florbetaben (BAY94-9172)positron emission tomography (PET) is able to distinguish between subjects with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) progressing to Alzheimer's disease (AD) from those with MCI not progressing to AD.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: 26 subjects were screen failures and did not have study drug administered.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: A total of 71 patients were screened at one study center in Australia. The first subject's consent was obtained on 02 JUN 2008.

groups.title: MCI Subjects
groups.description: Subjects with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) receiving florbetaben (BAY94-9172) : single intravenous injection of 300 megaBecqerels (MBq) florbetaben, at baseline, at 12 and 24 months

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: All enrolled subjects who received at least one florbetaben (BAY94-9172) injection

groups.title: MCI Subjects
groups.description: Subjects with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) receiving florbetaben (BAY94-9172) : single intravenous injection 2 mL to 10 mL, at baseline, at 12 and 24 months

outcomeMeasures.title: Quantitative Assessment of Neocortical SUVRs (Mean Standard Uptake Value Ratios) as a Measure of Florbetaben Uptake
outcomeMeasures.description: Mean SUVRs were calculated for subjects who did and did not progress to Alzheimer's Disease (AD) during the study for each PET scan time point (baseline, 12 and 24 months)
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All subjects receiving study drug with PET scan data at the respective timepoint
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: 1 scanning period post injection to be evaluated at baseline, 12 months and 24 months

groups.title: Not Progressed to AD (Baseline)
groups.description: Mean SUVR for the baseline PET scan in subjects who did not progress to AD during the study

groups.title: Progressed to AD (Baseline)
groups.description: Mean SUVR for the baseline PET scan in subjects who progressed to AD during the study

groups.title: Not Progressed to AD (12 Month)
groups.description: Mean SUVR for the 12 month PET scan in subjects who did not progress to AD during the study

groups.title: Progressed to AD (12 Month)
groups.description: Mean SUVR for the 12 month PET scan in subjects who progressed to AD during the study

groups.title: Not Progressed to AD (24 Month)
groups.description: Mean SUVR for the 24 month PET scan in subjects who did not progress to AD during the study

groups.description: Mean SUVR for the 24 month PET scan in subjects who progressed to AD during the study

analyses.groupDescription: The baseline neocortical SUVR in those subjects who progressed to AD over the 2 year follow-up was compared to the neocortical SUVR of those that did not progress by a Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test.
The 12 month neocortical SUVR in those subjects who progressed to AD over the 2 year follow-up was compared to the neocortical SUVR of those that did not progress by a Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test.
The 24 month neocortical SUVR in those subjects who progressed to AD over the 2 year follow-up was compared to the neocortical SUVR of those that did not progress by a Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Normal and Abnormal Scans in Patients With MCI Progressing to AD and Those Who do Not Progress Based on a Threshold of Neocortical SUVR=1.4
outcomeMeasures.description: This outcome measure showed the number of abnormal scans in subjects with MCI progressing to AD and those who did not progress compared to subjects with normal scans that did not progress and those who did progress.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: 1 scanning period post injection to be evaluated at baseline, at 12 months and at 24 months

groups.description: Results from 12 month scan for participants with progression from MCI to AD within 2 years after baseline scan.

groups.title: Progressed to AD (24 Month)
groups.description: Results from 24 month scan for participants with progression from MCI to AD within 2 years after baseline scan.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number and Proportion of Normal and Abnormal Scans Based on Brain ß-amyloid Plaque Load (BAPL) in Subjects With MCI Converting to AD and Those Who do Not Progress
outcomeMeasures.description: At each study time point (baseline, 12 months and 24 months) PET images were obtained at 45 min and again at 90 post injection. These images were assigned a BAPL score of 1, 2 or 3 based on the reader's evaluation of the scan. A BAPL scores of 1 was considered normal, and scores of 2 and 3 were considered abnormal. These scores were compared to subjects clinical diagnosis for AD at the end of the study follow up period.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All subjects with PET data at the referenced study time point
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: 2 scanning periods post injection to be evaluated each at baseline, at 12 months, and at 24 months

outcomeMeasures.title: Sensitivity/Specificity/Negative Predictive Value (NPV)/Positive Predictive Value (PPV) at Baseline, 12, and 24 Months in the Detection of Significant Brain ß-amyloid Plaque Load in Patients With MCI Progressing to AD Compared to Those Who do Not Progress
outcomeMeasures.description:
Sensitivity, specificity, NPV and PPV were measured based on subject BAPL scores by time point and imaging window, compared to clinical diagnosis of AD during the study period. A BAPL score of 1 was considered negative for the presence of beta-amyloid, and scores of 2 and 3 were considered positive.

For this study, sensitivity was defined as the percentage of subjects with a clinical diagnosis of AD who also had a positive PET scan (BAPL score of 2 or 3) at the respective time point.

Specificity was defined as the percentage of subjects with a clinical diagnosis of non-AD who also had a negative PET scan (BAPL score of 0 or 1) at the respective time point.

PPV was defined as the probability that a subject with a positive PET scan would have a clinical diagnosis of AD sometime during the 2 year follow up period.

NPV was defined as the probability that a subject with a negative PET scan would not have a clinical diagnosis of AD at any point during the 2 year follow up period.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All subjects with PET data at the referenced study time point
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: 2 scanning periods post injection to be evaluated at baseline

pointOfContact.title: Juergen Hirschfeld, Senior Director Regulatory Affairs

drug: Florbetaben (BAY94-9172) — an 18F-labelled PET tracer for β-amyloid (diagnostic imaging agent)
explanation_target: Reason: The study uses Florbetaben (BAY94-9172) PET to identify β-amyloid in vivo and to distinguish MCI subjects who progress to Alzheimer's disease from those who do not. Florbetaben is an 18F-labelled amyloid PET tracer that binds fibrillar Aβ and is used for diagnostic imaging, not as a therapeutic agent intended to modify disease, improve cognition, or treat neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Act: Extracted details and classification decision — Intervention: Florbetaben (BAY94-9172), an imaging tracer for β-amyloid (18F). Intended effect in the trial: diagnostic detection/prediction of progression from MCI to AD (biomarker/imaging), not therapeutic benefit. Matching to categories: not a biologic therapeutic, not a small-molecule therapeutic intended to alter pathology, not a cognitive enhancer, and not an intervention for neuropsychiatric symptoms; therefore the correct category is 'N/A' (diagnostic/non-therapeutic). citeturn0search2turn0search3

Reflect: Confirmation — the cited literature and the clinical trial record describe florbetaben as a PET imaging ligand for β-amyloid used for in vivo mapping and diagnostic discrimination (proof-of-mechanism and clinical trial entries). This aligns with classifying the trial as diagnostic (N/A) rather than one of the four therapeutic categories. No evidence in the trial description indicates a therapeutic intent or a placebo-controlled treatment arm. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Web search results (sources used): 1) PubMed — 'Imaging of amyloid beta in Alzheimer's disease with 18F-BAY94-9172, a novel PET tracer: proof of mechanism' (describes 18F-BAY94-9172 florbetaben binding to Aβ and discriminating AD from controls). citeturn0search0 2) PubMed — 'Individualized quantification... proof of mechanism phase 0 florbetaben PET trial' (describes florbetaben as a β-amyloid PET tracer used in clinical development). citeturn0search2 3) Bayer/Clinical trial listing for NCT01138111 (trial description: Florbetaben (BAY94-9172) PET imaging in MCI to test ability to distinguish progressors vs non-progressors; diagnostic purpose). citeturn0search3 4) Trial listing summaries (MedPath/clinical trial aggregation) with study details and endpoints for florbetaben PET in MCI. citeturn0search4
